subject: Re: [junit] Can't run anything from textui?
msgSnippet: ... Can t be: you re referring to the test case class as TestTest , which is in the default package. Don t do that. Now you might mean I ve tried the same
messageBody:
Ryan Platte wrote:
> On Mar 18, 2005, at 8:21 PM, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>
> >> 1. TestTest.java is the following: =====
> >>
> >> public class TestTest extends junit.framework.TestCase {
> >> public void testRunnin() {
> >> assertFalse("failure works!", true);
> >> }
> >> }
> >>
> >> =====
> >>
> >> 2. I compile it with "javac TestTest.java". TestTest.class appears.
> >>
> >> 3. I do:
> >> $ java -cp ~/Desktop/Downloads/junit3.8.1:. junit.textui.TestRunner
> >> TestTest
> >>
> >> and get:
> >> Class not found "TestTest"
> >>
> >> 4. I do:
> >> $ java -cp ~/Desktop/Downloads/junit3.8.1:. junit.swingui.TestRunner
> >> TestTest
> >>
> >> and get the failure I expect ("failure works!").
> >
> > It's in the default package, isn't it? Not a good idea.
>
> This is a reduction. I get the same thing when the test is in a
> non-default package.

Can't be: you're referring to the test case class as "TestTest", which
is in the default package. Don't do that.

Now you might mean "I've tried the same thing when TestTest is not in
the default package, such as com.mycom.TestTest". If that's the case,
then ignore the foregoing.

> I've worked around the issue by creating an AllTests class with a main
> method, but I would very much like to know what I'm doing wrong, or if
> textui isn't supposed to work this way, or if there's a bug (which I
> doubt).

The text-based UI certainly does work that way, but the above won't work
because TestTest is in the default package. If you can put your source
in a .zip and throw it in the files section, we can look more closely at it.
--
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
Diaspar Software Services
http://www.diasparsoftware.com
Author, JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
